What do I mean in my sutra when I say... up to... the twelve links of dependent arising definitely have conditioned arising.
According to Seng Liang:
The conditioned is impermanent, the unconditioned is permanent.
There are two kinds:
One is the impermanence of annihilation, which is not related to sentient beings;
The other is the impermanence of non-annihilation, which is the twelve links of dependent arising.
Permanence also has two kinds:
The permanence of arising and ceasing is the twelve links of dependent arising;
The permanence of non-arising and non-ceasing refers to nirvana.
This is the twelve links of dependent arising being both permanent and impermanent.
Some hear that dependent arising arises and ceases, and immediately think it is the same as plants and trees;
Hearing about non-arising and non-ceasing, they think it is the same as nirvana, and give rise to disputes.
Seng Zong said:
This is the sixth dispute.
If we discuss the correct meaning, the twelve causes and effects arise from each other, and it is exhausted in the Buddha.
Now, the reason why grasping at the conditioned becomes mistaken is because it is said that from birth to old age and death, it is cut off and does not continue, contradicting continuity;
As for saying it is unconditioned, it means there is no cutting off at all.
Bao Liang said:
The twelve links of dependent origination are indeed conditioned.

The reason why speaking of the conditioned becomes a dispute is because it does not make the conditioned of cause and effect continue, meaning that each individual entity is cut off and there is no further cause and effect.
Another time I told the bhiká¹£us... up to... whether there is a Buddha or not, the nature and characteristics always abide.
Seng Liang said:
Because the continuity does not change, it is called eternal.
Good sons!
The twelve conditions do not arise from conditions... up to... explaining the twelve conditions are definitely unconditioned.
Seng Liang said:
Although four sentences are cited, only the first sentence is used to explain the cause of giving rise to delusion.
Not arising from conditions means not yet combining with conditions.
Arising from conditions but not the twelve conditions means that since it does not have the twelve, it is said to be not the twelve.
Bao Liang said:

The second sentence says there are twelve conditions that do not arise from conditions, referring to the twelve branches in the future. Since the future has not yet arisen, it is said not to arise from conditions;
But some say it is permanent and therefore does not arise from conditions.
This is based on the teachings of the past. However, those who insist on one side say it is conditioned and has no continuity. Both sides are wrong, so they argue.
Good man!
In my sutras, I say all sentient beings... proclaim that the Buddha says the mind is definitely permanent.
According to Seng Liang:
Form has different characteristics, so it is said to perish, but the mind has no different characteristics, so it is said to be permanent.
Some, hearing that form perishes while the mind is constant, then say that the mind is not born and ceases, and goes from the lower to the higher.
Seng Zong said:
The seventh dispute.
If discussing the correct principle, in reality, the dharma ceases before and is born later. In terms of provisional names, it is one from beginning to end.
Some, hearing the teaching of the mind going upwards, do not understand the continuity, and say that this mind is constant and does not cease, going upwards to receive birth.
Good sons, at one time I was for BimbisÄra, up to singing, saying the TathÄgata's mind is definitely cut off.
Case: Seng Liang said:
Hearing that the five aggregates are all destroyed, they then say that the mind is also like form, having differences such as large, small, long, and short, etc.
Seng Zong said:
Hearing the teaching of impermanence, they say that abandoning this aggregate body, the mind also ceases and is not continued.
Bao Liang said:
Saying constant is unilaterally not ceasing, saying cut off is suddenly without continuity, therefore forming a dispute.
Good sons!
In my sutras, I say that my disciples... It is said that indulging in the five desires definitely obstructs the right path.
Seng Liang says:
Non-Buddhists take asceticism as the path, so they lie in ashes and eat bran.
The Buddha's teachings are not like this.
But some, hearing that being in desire does not obstruct [the path], think that even when the mind of desire is present, it does not obstruct the path;
Hearing that the mind of desire is an obstruction, they think that even things like fragrant flowers can obstruct the path;
Therefore, disputes arise.
Good man!
In my sutras, I say to stay far away from afflictions... It is said that the foremost teaching is in the formless realm.
Seng Liang says:
It speaks of the fruit of arhatship.
There are no arhats in the desire realm.
All concentrations in the three realms can cultivate the foremost teaching, enter the path of seeing the truth, and only exclude the one ground of non-perception.
The Buddha speaks differently according to the circumstances, but some, each according to what they have heard, give rise to disputes with biased attachments.
When cultivating the first dharma, one is able to subdue the bonds of views and is called far removed;
Because one has not yet seen the four truths and has not yet completely eliminated them, one has not yet attained liberation and is in the first dhyÄna.

As for reaching the fourth dhyÄna, the concentration of the desire realm has little wisdom and much concentration, the formless realm has much wisdom and little concentration, and the form realm has equal concentration and wisdom and is easy to use, so it speaks of the easy place.
Some people then think that one is not able to do it in the upper and lower realms.
As for attaining the fruit of the non-returner, this sÅ«tra does not speak of transcendence.

As for attaining the third fruit, the bonds below the three emptinesses have already been subdued and eliminated. When seeing the truth, the sharp observation of the uncontaminated path, although passing through the first fruit, ultimately does not abide.
Now it only speaks of the place of abiding.
Seng Zong said:
This is the ninth dispute.
If discussing the correct principle, the mind of the desire realm and the mind of the four dhyÄnas are all able to contemplate the supreme worldly dharmas.
The three emptinesses can also be attained, but the mind of this stage is difficult to use, so people do not follow the difficult and often take the easy.
Each stage is all about subduing the bonds, but at that time one has not yet attained true undefiled [wisdom].
If one has sharp faculties, while in the desire realm, one can fully perfect the mind of the upper stages and subdue the bonds of the upper stages.
Those with dull faculties may not necessarily be able to do so, and must be born in stages.
It is for those with sharp faculties that the first dharma is said to be in the desire realm.
Not understanding the Buddha's intention, they consider it to be only in the desire realm and that the mind of the dhyÄna stages cannot be used.

If one hears it said that the four dhyÄnas are used to cultivate the four kinds of contemplation, whether it is from the mind of the fundamental stage or not, they consider it to be only not used in the desire realm, because it goes against the middle way, and thus there is dispute.
Baoliang says:
From the perspective of principle, one can attain the first dharma when the mind of the three realms is exhausted.

There are those who have not yet attained the eight dhyÄnas, but only attain the lightning-like concentration of the desire realm, and still use this concentration to cultivate the nominal emptiness of dharmas.
Therefore, the Buddha said that this person uses the mind of the desire realm to cultivate it.
There are also those who attain the eight dhyÄna concentrations and cultivate the nominal emptiness of dharmas.
There are also those who first subdue the bonds up to the three emptinesses, and encounter the sages in those stages, and use the three emptiness concentrations to cultivate the first dharma.
But some do not understand, and having heard that it is cultivated with the mind of the desire realm, they say that it cannot be cultivated in the upper two realms;
having heard that it can be cultivated in the upper three realms, they again say that it cannot be cultivated in the desire realm, and thus disputes arise.
Zhixiu says:
One can cultivate the first dharma in both the two realms.
Ming Jun analyzes:
The above explanations all rely on the meaning of the Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra.
If one relies on the meaning of the Abhidharma, it can only be cultivated in the two realms, and the four emptiness concentrations cannot be cultivated at all.
Why is that?
It means that even from the stage of superior patience and above, one still cannot take it as an object;
How much less so the first dharma, which resembles the uncontaminated, could it be taken as an object?
The meaning and characteristics should be carefully examined by the wise.
Good sons!
In my sutras, I have said that among the four kinds of giving, up to proclaiming that the Buddha says giving is only the mind.
According to Seng Liang:
The actions of body, speech, and mind are all the essence of giving, with pure and impure, then the blessings are thick, and the impure blessings are thin.
Purity must be due to faith, there is mental purity.
The first three:
One possesses both purities;
The other two have faith and mind.
Although there are superior and inferior, they are all considered pure.
But some, hearing that pure giving is due to faith, and faith is a mental action, then consider that the requisites for giving are in the mind, thus giving rise to disputes.
Good sons!
I once again said, up to proclaiming that the Buddha says giving is the five aggregates.
According to Seng Liang:
The Buddha speaks of the effect in the cause, referring to the five things to be given.
Some, hearing that food is the act of giving, think that anything that can be given externally is giving.
The five aggregates encompass all phenomena, so it is said that giving is the five aggregates.
Seng Zong said:
This is the tenth dispute.

From the perspective of the correct principle, the mind is the master of giving and so forth, while form assists. The body and speech assist the mind, but the body and speech are not the laws of the spiritual mind.
Hearing that the two kinds are pure, one thinks that it is only the mental activity, not related to body and speech;
Hearing that giving is the five things, one thinks that it is only form, not the mind, and disputes again.
Bao Liang said:

If one has practiced for a long time, accomplished the mind of giving, and always practices in all situations, the Buddha speaks for this person that giving is the mind, not waiting for body and speech to be accomplished.
There are also people whose wholesome roots are weak, who need the assistance of body and speech to be able to give generously.

If one does not move the body or speech, but only gives rise to mental thoughts, it does not constitute the act of giving. The Buddha explains for such a person that giving consists of these five aggregates.
Some people misunderstand the Buddha's intention. If they hear that giving is only of the mind, then it has nothing to do with body and speech.
As for the statement that it consists of the five aggregates, it must be accomplished through the three karmas.
Both attachments are biased, and therefore they become a dispute.
Good man!
At one time I proclaimed the nirvana... up to the Buddha says there are no three unconditioned dharmas.
Seng Liang says:
The Buddha speaks of the two truths. In the worldly truth, there are causes. There are two kinds of causes:
One is with the function of dharmas, and the other is without the function of dharmas.
The one without the function of dharmas refers to the three unconditioned dharmas.
The one with the function of dharmas refers to the five aggregates.
Some people hear that nirvana can end birth and death, and then say that there are unconditioned dharmas that are included in the dharma-entry.
Hearing that there is no dharma, they say there is no nirvana that can end birth and death, and thus give rise to disputes.
When a lamp goes out, it simply means the light is extinguished, and no further extinguishing dharma arises.
Nirvana is also like this. It simply means the afflictions are extinguished, and no further dharma arises.
Because the afflictions are extinguished, birth and death do not continue. This function of no dharma is called emptiness.
This is the emptiness of general characteristics, and thus it is called permanent and all-pervading.
The emptiness of the world, such as the emptiness of horses, etc., is the emptiness of specific characteristics. It is also emptiness due to the absence of dharma. It is used as a metaphor.

Because of its specific characteristics, it is neither permanent nor all-pervading.ğŸ”½Non-cessation due to the condition of cognition refers to the cessation due to the condition of supramundane undefiled cognition;
non-cessation due to the condition of cognition refers to mundane undefiled [cessation].
Although there is a difference between the mundane and supramundane, the meaning of cessation is permanent, and it is the same as emptiness, and is called one of the three unconditioned dharmas.
Non-Buddhists cannot attain the undefiled cessation of bonds. The bonds cease and then arise again, and thus cannot be called permanent.
Sengzong said:
The eleventh dispute.
As for speaking from the correct principle, there are not no three unconditioned things, they are just three separate dharmas.
Baoying said:
Some say that there is nothing in emptiness, it cannot be distinguished, it is only one emptiness, there are no three unconditioned things.

The Buddha's intention here is that it can be said to exist, and it can also be said to not exist. Because emptiness is not a separate dharma, it is said to not exist. Because one seeks it according to the meaning, it is said to exist.
Good man!
At one time I spoke for MaudgalyÄyana, saying that the TathÄgata speaks of nirvÄá¹‡a.
Sengliang said:
Calling it nirvÄá¹‡a refers to the chapters and sentences.
What is practiced by the sages is called the traces.
Never regressing or losing it is called ultimate.
Not having the eight sufferings is called fearlessness.
Curing the illness of birth and death is called the great teacher.
The fruit, wisdom, forbearance, and unobstructed samÄdhi are all named according to different meanings.
The same characteristics as the Dharma are called the great Dharma realm.
Cutting off old age, sickness, and death is called the taste of immortality.
There is nothing to grasp, so it is called difficult to see.
Again, at one time I was for MaudgalyÄyana... definitely speaking of the existence of the unconditioned space.
Seng Liang said:
If there is a nature, the nature cannot be destroyed;
Because it has no nature, it is called not solid.
What is called empty space is that which has no nature and no Dharma, yet the Dharma has a function. It has the same nature as empty space, so it is named after that.

As for the food going down and turning back, it is said that all sounds follow each other, the food cannot go down, and the sound is not emitted. Because there is no single existence of food going down and sound being emitted, it explains the function of emptiness.
Some people hear that emptiness has a function and think there is a Dharma of emptiness, which is included in the Dharma entrance and the form entrance.
Again, at one time I was for MaudgalyÄyana, speaking... definitely speaking of the existence of the cessation not due to the elimination of contaminants.
Seng Liang said:
Extinguished by the condition of wisdom refers to not by supramundane uncontaminated wisdom.
From the peak of the summit up to the supreme worldly dharmas, these are mundane uncontaminated, permanently severing the three evil destinies.
Baoliang says:

If it is extinguished by the condition of wisdom, it is also called the unconditioned by the condition of wisdom.ğŸ”½Since emptiness is devoid of things, it can be distinguished from space, and is also called the unconditioned of space.
In emptiness, there is no further counting, and it is then called the unconditioned not conditioned by anything.
Those who do not understand the meaning, hearing of nonexistence, cannot accord with the meaning of the three existences. Hearing of existence, they say the three have separate substances.
Taking them as real things, they give rise to disputes.
Good man!
I also once for Balapramardin decisively said that form is the four great elements.
Seng Liang says:
The four great elements are called form. There are five forms of dharmas. The four great elements are provisional. Speaking of four is speaking of the complete exhaustion of what is seen.
Sound is produced by the four great elements. By mentioning the root, the branches are included.

To decisively say that form is the four great elements means that in the realm of form, the four great elements are always present together. Water has fire, boiling water has coolness. The sound in space also has the four great elements. This misses the point.
Seng Zong said:
This is the twelfth dispute.
If one says that the correct meaning is that form, smell, and taste make up the four great elements, and the four great elements further make up the five sense organs such as the eyes.
Although it is said to be fourteen kinds of form, if each nature is included, it does not go beyond the four great elements.
If the four great elements are the cause and the five sense organs are the effect, not leaving the effect there is the cause, it can be said to be made up of the cause.
Hearing that the four great elements are called form, not understanding the inclusion of natures, it is said that there are only the four great elements and no other form.

translated: Hearing that the four great elements are the cause and the five sense organs are the effect, it can be said that the formation of the sense organs is due to the great elements. Apart from the cause, there is no effect.
Up to slippery, if according to what is explained in the Four Elements chapter, all are not divided into four elements.

Not distinguishing this statement, it is said that the four elements of the past create the form of the three times. It is said that the form of present bodily and verbal karma exists because of the power of the thirty-four elements of the past. The present creates two times, and the future only creates one time.
Not understanding the Buddha's intention, they again argue.
Bao Liang said:
Some people say that the power of the four elements is strong and can create form, while the power of form is weak and cannot create the four elements.
They always make this calculation.
Once the Buddha was for the sake of the bhiká¹£us.
He spoke of the emptiness of the extinction of the five aggregates. What is form?
Form is the four elements.
They say that the four elements cannot create form.
Again, at one time he spoke of the four elements creating form, namely the square, round, etc., this is the cause of waiting for the internal characteristics.
Those who hear this explanation say that the four great elements definitely give rise to form.
If discussing the middle way or the correct principle, one should say that they both give rise to and do not give rise to.
What is the reason?
Because the various provisional forms such as square and round arise based on the four great elements, it is also said that they give rise to.
The previous six great elements and the subsequent four great elements do not give rise to.
The five sense objects are also like this. Because the coarse is formed based on the subtle, it can also be said that form gives rise to form.
Since the previous is form and the subsequent is also form, it is said that they do not give rise to.
People do not understand. Hearing that they give rise to, they make everything give rise. Hearing that they do not give rise, they say that everything does not give rise.
Both giving rise and not giving rise lose the middle way, and therefore disputes arise.
Good man!
I also say, It is like the mirror giving rise to images. This is called giving rise to form, like an echo or a reflection.
According to Seng Liang:
The four great elements are provisionally named and have functions. Firmness, wind moves, water moistens, fire ripens, and form can grow. It is like an image appearing due to a mirror.
My disciples, having heard this teaching, say that if there are the four great elements, then there are derivative form.
Seng Liang says:
It is said that the four great elements can create, but are not created.
Form is created, but cannot create.
Sometimes there are the four great elements, but no derivative form.
Seng Liang says:
It is said that the four great elements are provisional, and are created by real dharmas.
Form and other real dharmas are not created. The Buddha says that creation creates. The four great elements also create form, just as bundles of bamboo support each other to stand.
The above two parties' biased attachments both do not understand the Buddha's meaning.
Good man!
In the past, once the Prince of Enlightenment said... not losing the precepts, still called upholding the precepts.
Seng Liang says:
Non-action is the essence of the precepts.
This explains the ten good precepts. The seven branches of body and speech arise from manifested form and produce unmanifested form, which is form;
The remaining three do not arise from manifestation and are not called form.
Sengzong said:
The thirteenth dispute.
If discussing the correct principle, unmanifested action is not mind.
Although it is not form or mind, it cannot be said to be nonexistent.
This is the nature of good dharmas that opposes evil. Because the effect is explained in terms of the cause, it is said that unmanifested action is form.
It is obtained from form and is named after the cause.
Some people hear this and do not understand, so they say unmanifested action is form.
Baoyuang said:

For Prince Bodhi, it is said that unmanifested action is form. If it is directly said that mind is precepts, the prince would think that when an evil mind arises, the precepts received are all lost, and then there would be no precepts to uphold. Therefore, the unmanifested precepts are explained in terms of the seven branches of body and speech.
Those who mistakenly take the Buddha's meaning say that simply being without fabrication is morality, and it has nothing to do with the mind.
Moreover, they say that morality is precisely the prohibition against evil dharmas. If the mind does not do evil, that is morality.
Hearing this, they say that there is no morality of non-action at all.
This is why disputes arise.
For what reasons is it called non-action color, not a different color cause, not producing a different color effect?
According to Seng Liang:
As for not being a different color cause, the dharmas of bodily and verbal action are of the nature of form, with three kinds: good, evil, and neutral.
Morality takes good action as its cause. Good action is different from non-good and neutral, called a different color and a different color cause.
As for not producing a different color effect, non-action is the effect of a different color cause.
It is said that there is no difference in cause, and there is no such effect that is the same as the effect.
According to Seng Zong:
As for not being a different color cause, different color is precisely the substance of non-action.
If other forms do not give rise to non-action, they are not the cause of non-action, such as the form of neutral body and speech, and the form of mountains and rivers.
Since it is said that they are not the cause of different forms, different forms are also not its effect.
If the good form of body and speech can give rise to non-action, it is the cause of different forms, and different forms are also its effect.
Because it is attained by giving rise to good form, it is called non-action.
Because of not understanding, it is said that non-action is form.
Bao Liang said:
The cause of different forms refers to the mind. It clarifies that it is not only the mind that acts as the cause.
The effect of the cause of different is this precept. This precept is also not only the effect of the mind. It must be the combination of form and mind that is called the good of precepts.
Dao Hui's notes say:
This clarifies that in order to give rise to non-action, one must first properly join one's palms and make an extraordinary form, and then one can give rise to this effect of non-action.
Zhi Xiu said:
The mind is not the body or speech, and is called different from form.
The body and speech have no activity, and do not arise from it, therefore it is said not to be different from form as a cause.
Not making different form causes and effects means not making the mind a result, therefore it is said not to make the result of a cause that is different from form.
Hui Lang separately states another explanation, saying:
Non-action is different from form. If it is not the cause of different form, then it does not make the result of different form.
Good sons!
My disciples, having heard this teaching, proclaim that the Buddha says there is non-active form.
Seng Liang says:
The Buddha's intention is that non-action is not form, but arises from form, and is named form from its cause.
Not understanding the Buddha's intention, they say non-action is the nature of form.
Good sons!
I have said in other sutras... definitely proclaim that there is no non-active form.
Seng Liang says:
Vowing not to do evil, the non-active precepts arise, and can restrain evil dharmas.
Not committing evil is called observing precepts. When not committing evil, non-action alone arises. The nature of precepts is clear and pure, which is called observing precepts.
If one gives rise to committing evil, precepts and evil occur simultaneously. Precepts are not clear and pure, because it violates the original vow, it is not called observing precepts.
Not understanding the Buddha's intention, hearing the teaching of non-action, one thinks there is no further dharma of action, and no non-action.
Good man!
I speak like this in the sutra... all ordinary people are also like this.
Commentary by Seng Liang:
The sutra says that suffering and happiness are dominated by the mind.
The mind has understanding and delusion. Delusion is called ignorance, and understanding is called right view.
Right view is the cause of happiness, and ignorance is the root of suffering. These two are the different abilities of the mind.
They are established as the dharma of numbers. The five aggregates are suffering, arising from ignorance. This explains the faults of delusion.
Commentary by Seng Zong:
The fourteenth dispute.
Sometimes it is said that there are mental factors, and sometimes it is said that there are no mental factors.
If we discuss the correct principle, the mind and its associated mental factors are both existent and non-existent.
As for saying there are mental factors, they arise in sequence before and after.
As for saying there are no mental factors, it means they do not exist simultaneously.
Bao Liang said:
The Buddha once said that whether it is ordinary beings or sages, the five aggregates are all caused by ignorance, and so are the twelve links.
Some people do not understand and say that there is only this one ignorance, and there is no further mutual causation in the middle, but just one thing that is always so.
They just make different names and explanations, saying there are twelve links, and then declare that there are no mental factors.
Zhi Xiu said:
Because the Buddha spoke of the twelve conditions and two sections of cause and effect, two schools arose in their interpretation.
The first clarifies the past causes, which have three constant changes:
First, from the link of ignorance, the links of craving and grasping are produced;
Second, the branch of transformation is called by name;
Third, it is said on the basis of the fruit that it is the cause.
Next, the five fruits are distinguished, which have five differences:
First, changing consciousness to feeling;
Second, speaking of the cause on the basis of the fruit;
Third, the various branches are extensively produced after name-and-form;
Fourth, the two branches of contact and feeling are briefly mentioned;
Fifth, speaking of the fruit on the basis of the branch of feeling.
Some people, because of this, hold that there are no mental factors. Next, the three causes and two fruits are spoken of.
In speaking of the three causes, two things are changed from the norm:
First, the eye consciousness and so forth are produced before the branch of feeling;
Second, the name of karma is transformed.
In speaking of the two fruits, two things are changed from the norm:
First, the branch of birth is changed to consciousness;
Second, old age and death are divided and the names of the various branches are extensively produced, because it is said that conceptualization and so forth are not the same as contact.
Some people, because of this, hold that there are mental factors that arise simultaneously.
Dao Hui's commentary says:
The difference between the mind before and after is simply called number.
If it is thought that before and after are still one mind, and there are no mental factors at all, this is also a mistake.
If it is said that in one moment there are separate mental factors arising together, this is also a mistake.
It should be known that from ignorance arises craving, up to this is ignorance, craving, and grasping.
Seng Liang says:

This explains the afflictions arising in the present life, clarifying that there are no separate mental factors, but they arise from conditions, either lightly or heavily, as the four [parts of the twelve links].
What is it?
The mind not understanding conditions, not taking the good as good, is called ignorance.
Attachment to the good gives rise to defilement, which is called craving.
The nature of craving is to seek greedily, which is called grasping.
Giving rise to bodily and verbal actions is called existence.

The reason it is said to be the same is that the original name is not lost, but it is changed according to the heavy [part]. The essence has both establishment and distinction, serving as separate mental factors.
Seng Zong says:
If we discuss the sequential arising of cause and effect, the preceding cause and subsequent effect are not simultaneous.

There may be no sequence, such as ignorance being the cause for karmic formations, there may be arising of subtle afflictions from coarse afflictions, up to the meaning of being able to create again after exhausting craving and feeling.
This is the sequential arising of the characteristics of conditions.
Ignorance is craving, craving is ignorance, from beginning to end it is a single spiritual awareness. Although cause and effect are different, they cannot be separated, so it is said to be the same.
From existence arises feeling, you should know that this feeling... up to therefore the experiencer is the twelve branches.
Commentary by Seng Liang says:
Feeling is the initial consciousness branch.
Consciousness is able to receive birth, so it is called feeling.
Commentary by Daohui says:
